Element types: normal flow.back:
Normal flow -	left-to-right, top-to-bottom rendering of text in Western Lang
most elements are in normal flow only way to leave it is to be floated or positioned

Element types: nonreplaced element.back: nonreplaced elemment -	an element whose content is contained within the document

Element types: replaced element.back:
replaced element -	an element that serves as a placeholder for something else.
img is the classic example

Element types: block-level element.back:
block-level element -	an element such as a paragraph, heading, or div.
These elements generate newlines both before
and after their boxes

Element types: inline element.back:
inline element -	an element such as strong or span.
these elements do not generate 'line breaks' before or after themselves
and they are decendents of block-level elements

Element types: root element.back:
root element -	the element at the top of the document tree.
In HTML documents, this is the html element

block-level elements: horizontal formatt.back:
margin-left(auto)
border-left
padding-left
width(auto)
padding-right
border-right
margin-right(auto)

block-level elements: vertical formattin.back:
margin-top(auto)
border-top
padding-top
height(auto)
padding-bottom
border-bottom
margin-bottom(auto)

using auto - horizontal.back:
...

p{margin-left: auto; margin-right: 100px; width: 100px;} /* 'auto' left margin evaluates to 200px */ p{margin-left: 100px; margin-right: 100px;} /* width evaluates to 200px */ (overconstrained) p{margin-left: 100px; margin-right: 100px; width: 100px;} /* right margin forced to be 200px */

using more than one auto - horizontal.back:
...

p{width: 100px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;} /* margins evaluates to 150px */ p{width: auto; margin-left: auto; margin-right: 100px;} /* margin-left evaluates to 0, width to 300px */ if all three are set auto them margins are set to 0

using auto - vertical.back:
simplest case, a block-level, normal-flow element with
height: auto is rendered just high enough to enclose
the line boxes of its inline content

if the block-level element has either top or bottom padding
or top or bottom borders, then the height
will be the distance from the top
ofthe outer top margin edge of its
topmost child, to the outer bottom margin edge
of its bottommost child

inline elements - anonymous text.back:
anonymous text -
string of text not contained in an inline element

inline elements - em box.back:
em box -
defined by the given font, otherwise known as the character box

inline elements - content area.back:
content area -
in nonreplaced elements:
*	box described by the em boxes of every character in the element strug together
*	the box described by the character glyphs in the element

in replaced elements:
*	the intrisic height of the element plus any margins, borders, or padding

inline elements - leading.back:
leading -
the difference between the values of font-size and line-height

inline elements - inline box.back:
inline box -
box described by the addition of the leading to the content area

inline elements - line box.back:
line box -
shortest box that bounds the highest and
lowest points on the inline boxes that are found in the line

inline nonreplaced elements - building b.back:
for inline nonreplaced or anonymous text, the value of font-size determines the height of content area.
line height needs to be considered, font-size of 15px and line-height of 21px
	content area is 21px
inline nonreplaced element of 24px inside a block-level element
of font-size 12px and line-height 12px will be 12px have a 12px line-height and 24px content height
so the inline box is smaller that the content area

inline nonreplaced elements - vertical a.back:
if you change the vertical alignment on the inline boxes,
this also pushes up the top of the line box upward

inline nonreplaced elements - scaling li.back:
the best way to set line-height is to use a raw numnber as the value.
this becomes the scaling factor and is inherited not computed
example:line-height to be 1.5x their font-size:
body{line-height: 1.5;}

inline replaced elements.back:
inline replaced elements have an intrisic height and width that can cause the
line box to become taler than normal. This doesn't change the line-height for any element
in the line, including the replaced element itself.
instead the line box grows to the entirety of the replaced element

inline block elements.back:
inline-block -
a hybrid of block-level and inline elements. An inline-block relates to other elements and content as an inline box.

run-in elements.back:
run-in element -
block/inline hybrid that can make some block-level elements an inline part of a following element.
Used in typography where a heading will appear as part of a paragraph of text
